Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a program of experimental research to explore the limits of our knowledge of certain subatomic particles, and of their interactions at the smallest length scale. The project investigates three systems: the pi meson, the muon (a more massive "cousin" of the electron), and the neutron, focusing on the intrinsic low-energy properties of each of them. Those properties are sensitive to some of the basic components of the Standard Model, which describes the number and basic characteristics of the known elementary particles. Determining these properties thus has the potential to uncover new physics beyond the Standard Model. The project aims to advance basic science in nuclear and elementary particle physics, contribute to building the nation's STEM talent by educating members of the new generation of the STEM workforce, while keeping in focus its diversity and tapping the broadest available talent pool, and, finally, to develop new tools in fundamental research with possible broader applications.

The proposed research continues an ongoing program of study of the electroweak and strong interactions at low energies. The immediate goals of the project are: (a) conclusion of the data analysis for the PEN experiment, a precise measurement of the electronic and radiative electronic rare decays of the pion (pi-e2 and pi-e2g), completed at the Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), and (b) assembly and commissioning of the apparatus for Nab, a program of precise measurements of the neutron beta decay parameters at the Spallation Neutron Source (SNS). The UVa group plays a leading role in both projects. As the work on PEN nears completion, focus will move to (c) the new precise measurement of the muon gyromagnetic ratio, the muon g-2 experiment at Fermilab. The goal of PEN is to reach the precision of 5 parts in 10,000 for the branching ratio of the electronic decay of the pion, which is the most accurate experimental test of lepton universality (LU) available. At present, precision of the pi-e2 decay measurements lags behind the SM theoretical predictions by more than an order of magnitude. A number of physics scenarios outside the SM would lead to LU violation. LU, and lepton properties in general, carry added significance due to developments in neutrino physics. Nab is a highly rate unpolarized measurement of the electron-antineutrino correlation parameter "a" with accuracy of a few parts in 1000, and the first measurement of the neutron decay parameter "b", the Fierz interference term. Nab aims to resolve the persistent inconsistencies in the determination of the nucleon axial vector form factor and, consequently, of the Vud term in the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa quark mixing matrix, and to provide new limits on possible extensions of the Standard Model, such as left-right symmetric models, leptoquarks, etc., by exploiting the unique advantages of neutron decay, one of the most basic and theoretically best understood processes in nuclear physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the reporting period the focus of this work has been on three main projects:

PEN Experiment, a precision measurement of the rare decay π+ → e+ + νe (also known as πe2 decay) at the level of 0.05% relative precision, accompanied by the study of radiative decays of the charged pion and muon.  The data set acquired prior to the reporting period includes over 22 million πe2 events, as well as over 200 million muon decay events, to be used as normalization. The reporting period was used for focused PEN data analysis, which has now been brought to the final stage. The branching ratio (probability) of the πe2 decay is extremely sensitive to certain physics processes not included in the Standard Model (SM) of particles and fields. This work is complementary to direct searches at the LHC at CERN. The PEN measurements were carried out at the Paul Scherrer Institute's Ring Accelerator in Villigen, Switzerland.  PEN a collaboration of 7 institutions from 5 countries, led by the University of Virginia (UVa) group.

The Nab experiment at the Spallation Neutron Source (SNS), Oak Ridge National Laboratory (ORNL),Tennessee, has the goal to improve the measurement precision of a, the electron-neutrino angular correlation in neutron beta decay n → p + e + ν, by an order of magnitude, from the current Δa/a = 5% to Δa/a = 0.1%. Nab also aims to measure b, the Fierz interference term, a subtle distortion of the electron energy spectrum in neutron beta decay, at the precision of Δb = 0.003. The parameter b vanishes in theStandard Model. Both measurements of a and b at the goal precision would severely oonstrain possible particles and processes beyond the SM. During the reporting period, the complex Nab magneto- electrostatic spectrometer has been delivered by Cryogenic Ltd, and installed at the SNS. The dedicated Si detectors, previously having beenn demonstrated to detect 30 keV protons, were used in actual beta decay measurements at Los Alamos National Lab, along with the Nab data acquisition system. Commissioning of the spectrometer at SNS is currently under way.  Actual measurements are expected to being in 2021. Nab is a collaboration of 7 US research groups with 3 groups from abroad, led by UVa and ORNL.

After the successfully completion, testing and installation of the Bias Voltage System for the SiPM photodetectors in Fermilab E989, the Muon g−2 experiment, our group shifted focus to working on the precise determination of the magnetic field. E989 aims to measure g − 2, the gyromagnetic ratio of the muon to the precision of ~150 ppb. This represents one of the most stringent and sensitive tests of the predictions of the SM, and its possible extensions.  During the reporting period three data acquisition runs were successfully completed, with Run 3 unfortunately cut short by the covid-19 shutdown of Fermilab.  Data taking for E989 will resume as soon as the lab reopens and accelerator and experiment operations are allowed

Applied research stemming from this and the preceding NSF awards: This group's broad expertise, developed over decades, in precision Monte Carlo simulation techniques with GEANT4, has enabled a novel collaboration with colleagues from the UVa Radiation Oncology and UVa Cancer Center on advanced applications in minimizing adverse effects of radiation therapy on lymphocite cells (lymphopoenia).  This work has resulted in encouraging new results, already presented at international conferences. Funding support for this line of applied medical physics research will be sought from the NIH.

Results of this work have been presented in some 11 journal articles, several conference proceedings and other published reports, and were presented at over 20 scientific meetings both in the US and abroad, by researchers supported by this NSF research award. Research work of three Ph.D. and one M.Sc. degree students has been sponsored by this NSF award, as well as one research scientist (for one year), succeeded by a postdoctoral research associate (for the remainder of the award). One Ph.D. thesis was defended in 2020, and one M.Sc. thesis in 2019. In all, some 6 undergraduate students were supported by this research award for portions of the reporting period. Senior members of the group have engaged in outreach to the wider community.
